feel.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to experience a particular physical feeling or emotion
feel.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: You can never tell what he’s feeling.
Stop exercising if you feel any pain.
I felt like I’d really achieved something.
I’m feeling a little better today.
When his dad left, he felt as though his world had turned upside-down.
feel.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to notice something that is happening to you, especially something that is touching you
feel.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: She felt his warm breath on her cheek.
The earthquake was felt as far south as San Diego.
She felt his arms go round her.
feel.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to give you a particular physical feeling, especially when you touch or hold something
feel.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: It’s nice fabric – it feels like velvet.
The house felt hot and stuffy.
My leg feels as if it’s broken.
feel.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: if a situation, event etc feels good, strange etc, that is the emotion or feeling that it gives you
feel.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: After twenty years, seeing him again felt very strange.
It’s been a year since her daughter died, but to her, it still feels like yesterday.
It felt wonderful to be wearing clean clothes again.
How does it feel to be 40?
feel.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to have a particular opinion, especially one that is based on your feelings, not on facts
feel.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: She felt sure she’d made the right decision.
Some of the parents felt the school wasn’t doing enough about bullying.
How would you feel about working with Nicole for a while?
What does your partner feel about all this?
feel.translation[0].definitions[4].note_: Feel is not usually used in the progressive in this meaning You say
I feel this is probably the right decision
I’m feeling this is probably the right decision
In more formal English, you say it is felt that when saying what many people think
It was felt that the experiment should be stopped
feel.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to touch something with your fingers to find out about it
feel.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: She felt his forehead. Perhaps he had a temperature.
Mum, feel this stone. Isn’t it smooth?
He could feel how damp his shirt was against his chest.
feel how hard/soft/rough etc something is
feel.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: Feel is a linking verb This type of verb links the subject of the sentence with an adjective or noun
She felt tired at the end of the day
feel.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a quality that something has that makes you feel or think a particular way about it
feel.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Despite their age, the photographs have a modern feel.
The restaurant has a nice relaxed feel about it.
feel.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: the way that something feels when you touch it
feel.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: I like the feel of this cloth.
feel.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: when you use your hands, body etc to feel something
feel.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: She found the light switch by feel.
